key_points: Derek Chauvin, the former police officer convicted of killing George Floyd, was sentenced to 22.5 years in prison.
Chauvin will have to serve two-thirds of his sentence (15 years) before being eligible for supervised release.
The sentence exceeded the Minnesota guideline range for the crime, reflecting the case's impact on society and police brutality awareness.
Judge Peter Cahill highlighted aggravating factors for the harsher sentence, including Chauvin's abuse of authority and particular cruelty towards Floyd.
Chauvin will remain in a restricted housing unit for his safety, with his final placement yet to be determined.
The trial and sentence have been a focal point in discussions about racial justice and police reform.
Family members of George Floyd and their attorney, Ben Crump, expressed a mix of acknowledgment for the historic sentence and the need for ongoing societal change.
Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison considered the sentencing a step towards justice but not sufficient on its own.
Chauvin made a brief statement offering his condolences to the Floyd family, citing pending legal matters for not speaking further.
Three other officers involved in Floyd's arrest face charges of aiding and abetting, with their trial set for March 2022.
spokespersons: Sarah Fitzgerald (Minnesota Department of Corrections spokesperson)
Bridgett Floyd (George Floyd's sister, founder of the George Floyd Memorial Foundation)
